<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">

<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>With many US colleges starting classes this week, I thought about whether I had any unique advice for students other than the classic “go to office hours,” “join all the clubs,” and “don’t schedule an 8am class on Friday” (all valid btw).</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">And while it probably isn’t a galaxy-brain take, I do have one thought to share with all the students reading this: Don’t hesitate to <em>switch</em>. The hyper-concentration of social and academic life on college campuses allows you to switch up what you’re doing at such little cost compared to the professional world. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So take advantage. If you’re not feeling inspired by your coursework this semester, explore classes in another department. Friend group getting toxic? There’s another one waiting on the next dorm floor.  </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Put another way, you’ll never be presented with such a buffet of opportunities and experiences as college affords, so don’t fill up on the stale dinner rolls. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">— Neal Freyman</p>
</div>
</td>
</tr>

</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>

<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
Q&A
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers With...Happiness Expert Dr. Laurie Santos
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/26/icebreakers-withhappiness-expert-dr-laurie-santos?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Dr. Laurie Santos" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82Mzk1L2RyX2xhdXJpZV9zYW50b3MuSlBHIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Dr. Laurie Santos</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Some college classes you’d never skip even if extremely hungover—like Dr. Laurie Santos’s “Psychology and the Good Life.” The class, which explores the science behind decision-making and what comprises a fulfilling life, is Yale’s most popular course in over 300 years.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Luckily for us, Santos doesn’t keep her happiness secrets confined to New Haven, and she released the newest season of her acclaimed podcast, <a href="http://podcasts.pushkin.fm/morningbrewhappinesslab?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>The Happiness Lab</em></a>, this month.  </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Santos was kind enough to grant us time during office hours to ask a few questions.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Given what we know about the relationship between nostalgia and happiness, what’s the optimal amount of pictures to take on vacation?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I think pictures are kind of a mixed bag. On the one hand, pictures can help us remember things better, which helps us to access all our fondest moments. But there’s also a problem with pictures—they often take us out of the moment. And one thing we need for forming new memories is to be paying attention. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So my advice is that if pictures help you stay present, if they cause you to attend to a scene and notice more things, then great. That’ll allow you to have a memento that will help you remember after the fact. But if taking pictures means that you're worrying about how your hair looks or forcing people out of the moment to take a picture, then they might not be such a good idea.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What are some tips on coping with rejection? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The most important tip is realizing that rejection really hurts. And neuroscience suggests that it hurts in the same way that an awful physical wound might hurt. That means we really need some rejection first aid—we need to treat the pain right away. The best thing we can do when we're feeling rejected is to remember why we're valuable. Take time to write down the things you like about yourself, why you’re valued. Literally write your values and strengths down to remember why you're important and why you matter.  </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">A second important method of rejection first aid is to get some social connection. Meet up with the people who really care about you, and if you can't meet up with them directly, then do some “social snacking” and just look at pictures of people who are close to you. Just like getting a snack when you're hungry, a little social snacking can help you feel a lot better.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>How does a person know when they are happy? Is there a way of quantifying it? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The best way to know if you're happy is to ask yourself, “How am I feeling right now?” There's no thermometer for happiness. Even as scientists, we do rely on people's self-reports. But the good news is that those self-reports are valid for happiness and well-being. Self-report measures seem to correlate with other important things like textual analyses of your journal entries or detailed interviews with your family. So really the best way to know if you're happy is to ask yourself.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Is it easier for someone who studies happiness for a living to be happier than someone who doesn't? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I think you're asking if I'm actually happier. And the answer is yes. Since teaching this class, I’ve gone up about a whole point on standard 10-point measures of well-being. One of the great things about being the person who teaches a happiness class is that I have to practice what I preach. Otherwise my students will notice and will call me out on it. And that means that I'm engaging in more gratitude lately. I'm taking more time to meditate. I'm doing all of the habits that I suggest to my students and my podcast listeners, and as the data might suggest, that has made me happier.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>You’ve spent a lot of time studying nonhuman animals. How often when you observe human behavior do you think, wow, I’m just looking at a bunch of monkeys?</strong><strong><br></strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Well, it happens a lot in department faculty meetings, I'll be honest. But joking aside, I think one of the things you learn when you study primates, in particular, is that humans really are just animals ultimately. Lots of the kinds of things that we worry about come from our biology, and really mirror what we see in our closest living relatives, which I kind of take heart in. It's nice to see that humans are connected to their own biology.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>If your life were made into a movie, what genre would it be and who would play you?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Well, statistically speaking, if my life were made into a movie it would probably be a documentary. Since it’s about my life. But if I had a choice I would love for it to be a comedy, and for me to be played by J.Lo.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There’s more of the interview we couldn’t fit into the newsletter. <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/icebreakers-withhappiness-expert-dr-laurie-santos?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Give it a read here</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity. </em></p>

<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
How to Deal With Micromanagers
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/make-work?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make It Work logo" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ask Shane here</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I like my boss, but how do I get them to stop micromanaging me?—Sam in London</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Since going remote, my own four-legged boss has taken to micromanaging my every move. Currently, his head can be found draped over my shoulder, no doubt poised to critique this advice. Chances are, neither my attention-hungry pal nor your IRL manager is doing much to increase our respective productivity.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Most micromanagers tend to have two things in common: They are well-intentioned, and they wouldn’t want to be considered a micromanager. Your boss likely became a manager in the first place because they excelled at a job (possibly yours) that they had a lot of control over. It can take time to relinquish that control and to fully trust someone else to be just as effective. Give a little grace, if you can afford it.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">While you’re being patient, also be preemptive. When you get a new project, ask your boss, “What would it look like if this were done perfectly?” Compel them to think about what they want ahead of time and to possibly even provide templates or examples, rather than interject on the fly. If they are nudging you for repeated updates, put a few reasonably distanced checkpoints on the calendar so that they know there’s a designated time set aside to pull up and debate the merits of Calibri vs. Helvetica (I’m a Garamond man, myself).</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Above all else, open the dialogue. Some people need (and want) more guidance than others. Does your boss know that their current style demotivates you? Very likely there are tasks that you would actually appreciate more direction on than others—let them know that, too. The <a href="https://situational.com/situational-leadership?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Situational Leadership</a> framework is a model I’ve benefited from putting into practice and a great place to start the conversation at any level. Finding ways to introduce resources like these can help to limit unnecessary micromanagement and strengthen leadership skills throughout your organization.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>I have a large blank wall in my office and would like to put a vinyl quote on the wall. Could be motivational, not necessarily team-related, but definitely work appropriate. Any suggestions?—Rachel in Florida</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">This seems like a fun one to crowdsource to Brew readers—anyone game to help Rachel out? I’ll lean on Michael Scott to help get us in formation by recommending an <em>Office</em> classic: “<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r8VCeh_Xtq8" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">I am Beyoncé, always</a>.”  </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? Have an idea for a quote for Rachel? </em><a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Write in here</em></a><em>. </em></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>And coming soon...HR Brew. Be one of the </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/24747517.1107/aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cubW9ybmluZ2JyZXcuY29tL2hyL3N1YnNjcmliZT91dG1fbWVkaXVtPW5ld3NsZXR0ZXImdXRtX3NvdXJjZT1jcm9zc3Byb21vJnV0bV9jYW1wYWlnbj1ocl9pbl9tb3JuaW5nYnJld18wODE0MjE/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B7b0506f5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>first subscribers</em></a><em> to our upcoming newsletter on all things human resources.</em></p>

</td>

<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
A Movie Pirate’s Life Just Got Easier
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/sameday-streaming-causes-movie-piracy-ramp?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="TV/movie theater " style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMzAzL3R2X21vdmllX3RoZWF0ZXIuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">What pirated movies used to look like: shaky camcorder recordings of movies taken in theaters and uploaded to piracy sites.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">What pirated movies look like now: 4K resolution and just a quick Google search away.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">So what changed? Theater owners are blaming the recent phenomenon of same-day releases for a spike in piracy. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>The backstory: </strong>After pushing back releases in 2020, many studios finally decided to debut their films in theaters—but with a streaming twist. <em>Black Widow</em>, <em>The Suicide Squad</em>, <em>Jungle Cruise</em>, and other would-be blockbusters <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/hollywood-movies-flood-piracy-sites-hours-after-release-11629797400?mod=e2tw" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">simultaneously debuted</a> in theaters and on streaming services in summer 2021. It’s a seismic departure from the traditional method of releasing films in theaters, then waiting 90 days to make them available on digital platforms.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">That 90-day window did a lot more than protect the egos of directors who insisted their movies must be viewed on big screens. According to the Motion Picture Association, simultaneous theater-streaming releases have led to a surge in the number of pirated films flooding the internet—<a href="https://screenrant.com/movie-piracy-2021-increase-streaming-impact/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">within minutes</a> of their streaming debuts.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Last weekend at CinemaCon, the biggest annual expo for theater owners and studios, Motion Picture Association CEO Charles Rivkin accused one piracy group of single-handedly bootlegging 4,600 new movies in the past year.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Black Widow</em> was the most pirated movie in the world for three weeks running after it was released on Disney+ and in theaters on July 9, according to piracy-monitoring site TorrentFreak. Other summer releases, including <em>The Suicide Squad</em> and <em>Jungle Cruise</em>, also topped piracy charts shortly after their digital debuts.</p>
<h2 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">That’s making a dent in box office revenue</h2>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Disney said <em>Black Widow</em> has earned $367 million at the global box office. But here’s what that headline number doesn’t tell you: A big chunk of the money came on the first day the movie was released in theaters...then <a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/business/business-news/theater-owners-sound-piracy-alarm-over-disney-black-widow-streaming-reveal-1234985460/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">declined precipitously</a> afterward in no small part due to pirated copies circulating the web.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Revenue for <em>Black Widow </em>plummeted 41% from Friday to Saturday of its opening weekend and 67% from its first to second weekend—the largest box office drop of any Marvel movie, ever. The National Association of Theater Owners directly blamed piracy for the “stunning collapse.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">While streaming platforms may recoup some money lost to piracy via digital rentals and subscriber growth (which has boomed for Disney+, HBO Max, and Netflix), theaters won’t see a cent of that. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">And depending on how their notoriously vague contracts are set up, neither will actors: Sources say piracy is one reason ScarJo is <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/scarlett-johansson-sues-disney-black-widow-11627675176?mod=article_inline" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">suing Disney+</a>.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Looking ahead…</strong>from thorny questions around actor compensation to surging piracy levels, the road to streaming glory has more potholes than media giants had anticipated.</p>

<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Open House
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that wants to know, “Were those dolphin statues on porpoise?” We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://media0.giphy.com/media/xs7iqdXbdSoGrq6yOI/giphy.gif" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="Indianapolis home, three levels with iron gate, curvy porch, curvy pool, circle windows, and stone wall" data-source="Zillow" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Zillow</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Today’s <a href="https://www.realtor.com/realestateandhomes-detail/4923-Kessler-Boulevard-East-Dr_Indianapolis_IN_46220_M30524-17992?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">featured property</a> is located in Indianapolis, IN, hometown of Kurt Vonnegut, Wes Montgomery, and the guy who wrote the music for “Take Me Out to the Ballgame.” This house has everything—a curvy porch, a curvy pool, and a window with a curvy top and bottom (aka a circle). A 29,500 square-foot house that gives a Midwestern twist to a classic rock-climbing wall. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Amenities include:</p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li><span>7 beds, 7.5 baths</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Five separate fireplaces</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>A multipurpose ballroom and conference center (yes, for real)</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>That kid who is photobombing a few of the pics</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much for the house only a mother could love? Scroll to the bottom of the newsletter to find out.</p>

#353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eWith many US colleges starting classes this week, I thought about whether I had any unique advice for students other than the classic “go to office hours,” “join all the clubs,” and “don’t schedule an 8am class on Friday” (all valid btw).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAnd while it probably isn’t a galaxy-brain take, I do have one thought to share with all the students reading this: Don’t hesitate to \u003cem\u003eswitch\u003c/em\u003e. The hyper-concentration of social and academic life on college campuses allows you to switch up what you’re doing at such little cost compared to the professional world. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo take advantage. If you’re not feeling inspired by your coursework this semester, explore classes in another department. Friend group getting toxic? There’s another one waiting on the next dorm floor.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003ePut another way, you’ll never be presented with such a buffet of opportunities and experiences as college affords, so don’t fill up on the stale dinner rolls. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e— Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nIcebreakers With...Happiness Expert Dr. Laurie Santos\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/26/icebreakers-withhappiness-expert-dr-laurie-santos?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Dr. Laurie Santos\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82Mzk1L2RyX2xhdXJpZV9zYW50b3MuSlBHIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eDr. Laurie Santos\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSome college classes you’d never skip even if extremely hungover—like Dr. Laurie Santos’s “Psychology and the Good Life.” The class, which explores the science behind decision-making and what comprises a fulfilling life, is Yale’s most popular course in over 300 years.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLuckily for us, Santos doesn’t keep her happiness secrets confined to New Haven, and she released the newest season of her acclaimed podcast, \u003ca href=\"http://podcasts.pushkin.fm/morningbrewhappinesslab?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe Happiness Lab\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, this month.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSantos was kind enough to grant us time during office hours to ask a few questions.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGiven what we know about the relationship between nostalgia and happiness, what’s the optimal amount of pictures to take on vacation?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI think pictures are kind of a mixed bag. On the one hand, pictures can help us remember things better, which helps us to access all our fondest moments. But there’s also a problem with pictures—they often take us out of the moment. And one thing we need for forming new memories is to be paying attention. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo my advice is that if pictures help you stay present, if they cause you to attend to a scene and notice more things, then great. That’ll allow you to have a memento that will help you remember after the fact. But if taking pictures means that you're worrying about how your hair looks or forcing people out of the moment to take a picture, then they might not be such a good idea.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat are some tips on coping with rejection? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe most important tip is realizing that rejection really hurts. And neuroscience suggests that it hurts in the same way that an awful physical wound might hurt. That means we really need some rejection first aid—we need to treat the pain right away. The best thing we can do when we're feeling rejected is to remember why we're valuable. Take time to write down the things you like about yourself, why you’re valued. Literally write your values and strengths down to remember why you're important and why you matter.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eA second important method of rejection first aid is to get some social connection. Meet up with the people who really care about you, and if you can't meet up with them directly, then do some “social snacking” and just look at pictures of people who are close to you. Just like getting a snack when you're hungry, a little social snacking can help you feel a lot better.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eHow does a person know when they are happy? Is there a way of quantifying it? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe best way to know if you're happy is to ask yourself, “How am I feeling right now?” There's no thermometer for happiness. Even as scientists, we do rely on people's self-reports. But the good news is that those self-reports are valid for happiness and well-being. Self-report measures seem to correlate with other important things like textual analyses of your journal entries or detailed interviews with your family. So really the best way to know if you're happy is to ask yourself.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIs it easier for someone who studies happiness for a living to be happier than someone who doesn't? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI think you're asking if I'm actually happier. And the answer is yes. Since teaching this class, I’ve gone up about a whole point on standard 10-point measures of well-being. One of the great things about being the person who teaches a happiness class is that I have to practice what I preach. Otherwise my students will notice and will call me out on it. And that means that I'm engaging in more gratitude lately. I'm taking more time to meditate. I'm doing all of the habits that I suggest to my students and my podcast listeners, and as the data might suggest, that has made me happier.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eYou’ve spent a lot of time studying nonhuman animals. How often when you observe human behavior do you think, wow, I’m just looking at a bunch of monkeys?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWell, it happens a lot in department faculty meetings, I'll be honest. But joking aside, I think one of the things you learn when you study primates, in particular, is that humans really are just animals ultimately. Lots of the kinds of things that we worry about come from our biology, and really mirror what we see in our closest living relatives, which I kind of take heart in. It's nice to see that humans are connected to their own biology.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIf your life were made into a movie, what genre would it be and who would play you?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWell, statistically speaking, if my life were made into a movie it would probably be a documentary. Since it’s about my life. But if I had a choice I would love for it to be a comedy, and for me to be played by J.Lo.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere’s more of the interview we couldn’t fit into the newsletter. \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/icebreakers-withhappiness-expert-dr-laurie-santos?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eGive it a read here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F08%2F26%2Ficebreakers-withhappiness-expert-dr-laurie-santos\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nHow to Deal With Micromanagers\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/make-work?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make It Work logo\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Anything bothering you at work? \u003ca href=\"https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eAsk Shane here\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI like my boss, but how do I get them to stop micromanaging me?—Sam in London\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSince going remote, my own four-legged boss has taken to micromanaging my every move. Currently, his head can be found draped over my shoulder, no doubt poised to critique this advice. Chances are, neither my attention-hungry pal nor your IRL manager is doing much to increase our respective productivity.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eMost micromanagers tend to have two things in common: They are well-intentioned, and they wouldn’t want to be considered a micromanager. Your boss likely became a manager in the first place because they excelled at a job (possibly yours) that they had a lot of control over. It can take time to relinquish that control and to fully trust someone else to be just as effective. Give a little grace, if you can afford it.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhile you’re being patient, also be preemptive. When you get a new project, ask your boss, “What would it look like if this were done perfectly?” Compel them to think about what they want ahead of time and to possibly even provide templates or examples, rather than interject on the fly. If they are nudging you for repeated updates, put a few reasonably distanced checkpoints on the calendar so that they know there’s a designated time set aside to pull up and debate the merits of Calibri vs. Helvetica (I’m a Garamond man, myself).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAbove all else, open the dialogue. Some people need (and want) more guidance than others. Does your boss know that their current style demotivates you? Very likely there are tasks that you would actually appreciate more direction on than others—let them know that, too. The \u003ca href=\"https://situational.com/situational-leadership?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eSituational Leadership\u003c/a\u003e framework is a model I’ve benefited from putting into practice and a great place to start the conversation at any level. Finding ways to introduce resources like these can help to limit unnecessary micromanagement and strengthen leadership skills throughout your organization.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eI have a large blank wall in my office and would like to put a vinyl quote on the wall. Could be motivational, not necessarily team-related, but definitely work appropriate. Any suggestions?—Rachel in Florida\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThis seems like a fun one to crowdsource to Brew readers—anyone game to help Rachel out? I’ll lean on Michael Scott to help get us in formation by recommending an \u003cem\u003eOffice\u003c/em\u003e classic: “\u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r8VCeh_Xtq8\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eI am Beyoncé, always\u003c/a\u003e.”  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave a question about work you want to ask Shane? Have an idea for a quote for Rachel? \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/fY1CGzyY?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eWrite in here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAnd coming soon...HR Brew. background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nA Movie Pirate’s Life Just Got Easier\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/sameday-streaming-causes-movie-piracy-ramp?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"TV/movie theater \" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMzAzL3R2X21vdmllX3RoZWF0ZXIuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhat pirated movies used to look like: shaky camcorder recordings of movies taken in theaters and uploaded to piracy sites.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhat pirated movies look like now: 4K resolution and just a quick Google search away.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eSo what changed? Theater owners are blaming the recent phenomenon of same-day releases for a spike in piracy. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eAfter pushing back releases in 2020, many studios finally decided to debut their films in theaters—but with a streaming twist. \u003cem\u003eBlack Widow\u003c/em\u003e, \u003cem\u003eThe Suicide Squad\u003c/em\u003e, \u003cem\u003eJungle Cruise\u003c/em\u003e, and other would-be blockbusters \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/hollywood-movies-flood-piracy-sites-hours-after-release-11629797400?mod=e2tw\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esimultaneously debuted\u003c/a\u003e in theaters and on streaming services in summer 2021. It’s a seismic departure from the traditional method of releasing films in theaters, then waiting 90 days to make them available on digital platforms.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThat 90-day window did a lot more than protect the egos of directors who insisted their movies must be viewed on big screens. According to the Motion Picture Association, simultaneous theater-streaming releases have led to a surge in the number of pirated films flooding the internet—\u003ca href=\"https://screenrant.com/movie-piracy-2021-increase-streaming-impact/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewithin minutes\u003c/a\u003e of their streaming debuts.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLast weekend at CinemaCon, the biggest annual expo for theater owners and studios, Motion Picture Association CEO Charles Rivkin accused one piracy group of single-handedly bootlegging 4,600 new movies in the past year.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eBlack Widow\u003c/em\u003e was the most pirated movie in the world for three weeks running after it was released on Disney+ and in theaters on July 9, according to piracy-monitoring site TorrentFreak. Other summer releases, including \u003cem\u003eThe Suicide Squad\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003eJungle Cruise\u003c/em\u003e, also topped piracy charts shortly after their digital debuts.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:18px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003eThat’s making a dent in box office revenue\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eDisney said \u003cem\u003eBlack Widow\u003c/em\u003e has earned $367 million at the global box office. But here’s what that headline number doesn’t tell you: A big chunk of the money came on the first day the movie was released in theaters...then \u003ca href=\"https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/business/business-news/theater-owners-sound-piracy-alarm-over-disney-black-widow-streaming-reveal-1234985460/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeclined precipitously\u003c/a\u003e afterward in no small part due to pirated copies circulating the web.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eRevenue for \u003cem\u003eBlack Widow \u003c/em\u003eplummeted 41% from Friday to Saturday of its opening weekend and 67% from its first to second weekend—the largest box office drop of any Marvel movie, ever. The National Association of Theater Owners directly blamed piracy for the “stunning collapse.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWhile streaming platforms may recoup some money lost to piracy via digital rentals and subscriber growth (which has boomed for Disney+, HBO Max, and Netflix), theaters won’t see a cent of that. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAnd depending on how their notoriously vague contracts are set up, neither will actors: Sources say piracy is one reason ScarJo is \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/scarlett-johansson-sues-disney-black-widow-11627675176?mod=article_inline\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esuing Disney+\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLooking ahead…\u003c/strong\u003efrom thorny questions around actor compensation to surging piracy levels, the road to streaming glory has more potholes than media giants had anticipated.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F08%2F27%2Fsameday-streaming-causes-movie-piracy-ramp\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
